aEDbFwPN1TPiZuyGPLkzyg.text: Food is OK.... good for London because the standard for authentic Chinese food in London isn't very high. However the service was pretty bad. It's as if they want to rush you out and get your money as soon as you are done eating! They have to be more patient with their customers.

PqzwNF3FBzHB_hGwjqlfhA.text: Whenever I would visit London, weekend dim sum was always here at Royal China. Maybe because I didn't live too far away...maybe because I didn't want to deal with Chinatown.  Or maybe, because it was easy to find (it's Baker Street!) when you're heading out with friends (as once before a premiership game).  Whatever the reason, the food here is nicely done, filling, and besides the occasional wait, worth the trip.

JNFmMBpSZWRudb92YEOJUw.text: We landed in London late after flying and waiting in airports all day, went in search of a pub and stumbled into Royal China by mistake.  Wow, were we glad we made that mistake!  It was about 915 pm, and we waited for a table, and still watched people rolling in until at least 1030 pm.  Good people watching as it seemed to be a hot spot for what we call yuppies in the states.We started with sesame prawns on toast, if you have not tried this, I highly recommend it!  We ate every bite, along with an order of delicious veggie spring rolls.  On to the entrees of lemony chicken and chicken in black bean sauce, definitely the best I have ever had in both categories.  They also bring a couple different sauces to the table which I would say to use sparingly until you get the right combination, but they were both delicious. Service was nearly flawless, just a little confusing at times.If you are looking for Chinese in London, go here.

NPwjP_tzypnyGqWj2LCW9g.text: They have the best dim sum in London!  I really miss this place.  My mate and I used to go here for lunch and have to have a rather large table for everything that we ordered.  The best were the bbq pork buns!  Actually I don't think I ever had a bad meal there.  Well worth to trek to get there if you aren't near Marylebone!

nXkhnUbaG6hvgfV2XPfGcw.text: Coz I'm a Hong Kongnese NY'r i always crave dim sum when I'm travelling. If you are a dim sum connoisseur you'll know that dim sum in NY is crap. So from past experiences Royal China in London has always satisfied my cravings. Now that it has basically cornered the market in London with over 6 locations it has become mass market. I'm told that there is a main depot in zone 6 where all the dim sum is assembled and then shipped to the individual locations to be cooked. I didn't believe it until i tasted the dim sum and it tastes like the stuff i got from circle k or 7 eleven after a hard night at lkf or tst. Sorry London Royal China edges out most dim sum offerings in NY, but no where near Vancouver or Toronto standards - and for the price you'll be truly disappointed. True to the London experience - unfortunate. P.S the wait is horrendous 45 to 1hr no reservations, unless you are an insider (Cantonese).

R92HAX2mH6BOccvgLYWOtA.text: In my opinion, this is the best place to get dim sum in the city. The atmosphere in the restaurant is very traditional- it is a huge, smart restaurant full of business men during the week and wealthy families from St John's Wood at the weekend. Like the other Royal China's in London (Baker Street, Queensway and another in Canary Wharf) when you enter the restaurant, you are given a ticket and told to wait in the somewhat cramped bar area until your number is called out. Once you are led to your table and put your jacket on the back of your chair, the waiter abruptly covers your coat with a seat cover. The speed in which they do this shows the discipline of the restaurant- it is very smart, almost corporate in its feel, with an army of efficient waiters on hand at all times.The dimsum is the freshest and best I have tasted outside of Hong Kong. Although the restaurant's main menu is significantly more expensive than many chinese restaurants and it is undoubtedly more elegant, the dimsum selection is no more expensive than your typical dimsum restaurant in Chinatown. There is nothing more expensive than 4 pounds on the menu, which is incredible considering the quality and freshness of the ingredients. Everything here is freshly made on the premises- none of the frozen rubbish you get in soho. Having eaten dimsum here, it is really hard to go back to eating the packaged, reheated variety you typically find in London.

uoMbwN3lL0MSiqafyxJ-FQ.text: Big fan of the dim sum!

Vy8zJpzk6W1OQCb1wkXGcQ.text: Food so-so but service atrocious. First of all, there was very little service during the meal--our water was not refilled, no one asked us how the food was, etc. The waitress brought us the wrong food item and then when the bill came, we were charged for both items. Finally, when we tried to pay at the end, we asked to pay the "recommended tip" in cash while the meal was put on our credit card. The manager, Eddy Ho, came over and started berating us, saying we MUST charge both the meal and tip  on the credit card. He REFUSED to let us pay the tip by cash. He said that if we charged the meal only on our credit card and paid the tip separately, we were not allowed to come back to the restaurant! It was unbelievable. I have never seen such complete lack of customer service in a manager. He obviously did not care about keeping customers (or there is some scam going on).

nwOR39YzPrMA6Uqgac4ARw.text: Is possible to not give them any stars at all? Pretty good food, awful service.Very high and undeserved RECOMMENDED gratuity (except it is not recommended, after a long meal of horrible service I was FORCED, literally not allowed to leave the restaurant with out paying the included FULL gratuity.  The manager was immediately very rude before letting me explain myself.Also, on the way out, the receptionist refused to let us have the mints...we went to grab some from the bowl,  and she took it away and screamed "SORRY!"I will never go back, quite unfortunate I used to go almost every sunday and put up with the sub par service.

pPA4l-5W9BbaDtZeCksnug.text: The Baker Street branch of Royal China is the place to have dim sums or for a special dinner once a while. Unlike the Fulham Road branch this is vastly more spacious, staff infinitely friendlier and cooking is undoubtedly better.

w_GzLWRdKV9SEG_w7nFJRQ.text: Probably the best dim sum in the UK. The usual classics plus some more contemporary affairs in a nice inoffensive setting of traditional black lacquer. Service is good for a dim sum restaurant and prices are very reasonable given the quality.  If you want good and real dim sum in London this I s a hard place to beat.

Ub1ky4H35BaItk78XBX4zw.text: There was two Royal Chinas. This one is the less expensive one, but they still supply quality food. The service was mediocre, but the food was palatable.

96Lsb2xtFDWc-SLU8EBKkQ.text: Sure are there better Chinese but this an institution. Staff are "non- fussy" (terrible but efficient) but the food is as good as it will get at that price. Absolute favourite is dim sum sunday brunch .

XIQIFF7RoMAYzQNJjfFLqg.text: I've been coming here numerous times in past. The reason is because the food is so great. The service has always been below average, super frigid and unfriendly, but I decide to not pay any mind. However the last time I went was just the turning point that will never make us return anymore. We sat there for at least 15 minutes just waiting for sometime to take our order. The place was not even that busy. When we caught the waiters attention they just stare at us coldly and keep walking. Like I know it's not your department or area of responsibility but at least notify somebody we need assistance? Throughout the meal to ask for anything was sooo difficult because they kept ignoring. The check took about another 20 minutes because nobody cared serve us. Long story short. Service is too horrible.

UC5o02WPTyxS6RavL4z8AA.text: A nice place for a Chinese banquet in Marylebone. Great large tables that are perfect for big groups (10-12 people at a huge circle table with an equally huge lazy susan). The tables can be comically big if you have less than 10 people, which was the case for us last Friday night.The food was great---some of the best Chinese you can get in London. I suggest getting the set menus (minimum of 2 people). It's a bit pricey but you get tons of food---like 4 or 5 dishes. The aromatic duck pancakes were great as was this spicy shrimp stir-fry. So why not 5 stars, well the service is horrible...not very friendly or attentive. We sat down at 930, and they were very very eager to rush us out before closing time.Last pointer -- avoid the cocktails---I had 2 different ones---both were disgusting at best. You're here for the food not for the drinks.

zSi1K2BE3G9MIynT2B6E3w.text: This is a Great Chinese Restaurant to know in the area, nothing off, all delicious! Been going here for over a decade and it is still a solid good clean delicious Chinese. Gets packed, so call for reservations or get in early. Great to pop in after shopping off Oxford Street, this place is just on Baker St.  The egg rolls, the salt & Pepper prawns or squid, and the Pork dumplings are a great start! There is no wrong ordering here. It's all good!

O-X8d1S4mbRnQWb4kgLrKQ.text: Really bad experience! Having dinner with group of people. Royal China always overcharge if you spent more than  one thousand pounds! The people working in there always think that you will not read the bill!!!!  It is the second time they do this kind of things to us!  Being dishonest will not do any good  to your business at all! The reason they overcharge us probably because we are all Chinese and know that  Chinese always don't  read the bill! Shame on you!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Chinese
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. lobster
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

RNkoJH4mAeF0ewnNvUfksA.text: It only took me a year to get here, but we finally stopped by this past Sunday morning. And I'm very happy we did! My mantra as always: go early. They open at 11 on Sunday. We were there about 11:30; it filled up within the next fifteen minutes, and by the time we left, the queue was easily thirty-people deep. Their classics are spot on. We tried our usuals: har gao, char siu bao, lo pak ko, etc. However, we tried a braised pork and noodle dish that was underseasoned. The pork was also cooked within an inch of its life -- very tough. I think we'll stick with the basics, if we go back. It's definitely a younger, scene-ier crowd. Kind of like Yautcha, only cheaper. Worth a visit, if you're in the area.

_pXKWdTSViQAEN19t_h93A.text: went for Sunday dim sum, the food is great, both in terms of taste and varieties. service was efficient once we are seated. the restaurant itself is also nice, Chinese but not too over crowded that you need to shout in order to converse with people at your table. the only one thing I was annoyed is the inflexibility of having us to wait till the whole table arrive in order to be seated, after I have explained to them that our friends were on their way and were only shortly delayed due to issue with the kid. I don't really see the rational behind that we can not sit down and have a sip of tea already while we waited.

dUIFuYTz1yvFFfsPHpCm3g.text: Typical atmosphere when Chinese are in charge of the restaurant. Busy,noisy, fast service almost flying around the tables, no music, bright lights. Tables are big,  no intimacy feel whatsoever, so don't go there is you are in a romantic mood. Food is great though. I love crispy shredded fried spicy chicken and lemon chicken. In general - all dishes are good. When in Marylebone its one of best Chinese places there. Prices are not cheap but not really expensive either. Consider 50 quid for dinner for two with one round of drinks. Overall its nice food and they even to take away.

04SOP3fUJQTpUO9RL6vY0A.text: This is also another restaurant that deserves a 3.5 star.  This was the first dim sum I had in London and I have to say it was pretty good.  It was busy on a Sunday morning so be prepared to wait a little.There's nothing pretentious about the restaurant.  The food is hearty, there was a lot of variety and all at a very reasonable price.  You can leave here full for about £15 a head (maybe more if you're greedy).  This place could be an important hangover staple the next morning!

Ht0nU7Z4Mdh7GJeVBI0Oew.text: I come here often withy parents, mostly because they like this place so much.It is spacious which is very nice. Food is good, can't complaint about that.However, the waiters tend to take your plate away before you have a chance to finish your meal. It's like they want you out of there as soon as possible! Very unpleasant!

KSeNtuFZcc5ld7UAPWn-RA.text: It's not cheap, and it's not exactly mind blowing, but it was by no means awful. 3 stars because service was slow and I don't think the high price tag fit the quality of the dim sum. I wish it was more authentic as well.

EavE6aj8XgLkdTLk-tVvlw.text: A nice, classy Chinese place with fine Peking duck.  But the service is not that good, and it's a bit overpriced.

j7WKzib_yRoDXyliGZaQBA.text: Here for lunch today. Due to the inability of the people I was eating with to agree on what we should eat, we basically had everything, a soup each, then dim sum, then crispy duck, then various main courses with rice. I had a conference call after we ordered and came back to my soup (still warm) but all the dim sum had gone, which wasn't a major issue as I hadn't fancied the dim sum in the first place. The soup was great, I've had the duck with pancakes before and it lived up to its high standards, and the main courses were good - particularly the moroccan spiced lamb. On previous visits I've asked the waiting staff to choose the dishes for us, this normally works well and I recommend this course of action to non-Chinese visitors

abP0z72yR9o6LvnwPTgLVg.text: The quality of the food at Royal China is of very high quality.  The dim sum was magnificent along with the service & decor of the restaurant.

0x3GElYtKgPI5x4-jEKURA.text: I cannot come for a visit to London without my Royal China dim sum fix. Faves include the delicious sesame paper prawns, steamed prawn dumplings (plain version and its tasty sisters with chives or coriander). I always finish with the divine fluffy lotus seed bao!10 portions of dim sum are ample for three adults. If you're really hungry include noodles in your order.So good (and popular amongst the expat mumbai Desi crowd) that they've even opened a branch in Mumbai, India!I've been here for dinner too and it's also very good, but a tad expensive.

KSjmFED0bGgugPRtqc8Asg.text: This is my regular lunch/brunch spot when I visit London. I go there with a couple of my local friends to share dim sum/yum cha. I tried other places - including the famous Hakkasan, but I think this place is authentic and better. We always tend to order too much food, but we always ended up finishing all the dishes. :o Even with the London price (in a pricey neighborhood), I don't think it's too expensive. I also add - their service is very good, too!

WMOdIhusgxawXk217_8g9g.text: Best dim sum for the money in London. The only downside is the wait as it get very busy and they don't take reservations.

HYvJNPxyA2c15dYU50-f0w.text: Full post and photos @ thecattylife.com  Not to be confused with Royal China Club (its more expensive and less screaming-dimsum-orders-in-your-face sibling) Royal China has been a favourite amongst my pals for a while, but I don't know why I never went. Maybe it's the queues. Because if you show up any time after midday, there's a queue. Alternatively, you can be clever like my friends and send an anally-retentive-super-punctual friend (me) to get a ticket and commence the waiting. Used and abused, I tell you! Anyway, we ordered a bunch of the usual suspects  no wait, we diverted from the dim sum menu and ordered braised asparagus, which was perfectly crispy and soft (I realise them are oxymorons but they were crispy and soft, all at the same time)  har gow, siu mai, lo mai kai, wu kok, low bok gow, xiao long bao, and all kinds of cheong funs. Oh and a Singapore noodle because anally-retentive me had a craving. Everything was very good ~ fresh, tasty and light (as opposed to gruesomely glutnious which can be the norm at some substandard dim sum restaurants). I also remember that the law bok gow (turnip cake) was delicious with perfectly gelatinous consistency and beautifully fried a golden brown on each side. We also ordered I think five serves of cheong fun, which, well I think that means we liked it. Just a little bit. The desserts were a little bit bland but really, aren't we there for the dim sum?

DlheLfmmGVvjsIlU_jjcGA.text: While I still prefer the dim sum at New World (because they do the traditional cart service), I also have come to like Royal China...mostly because it feels a little more luxurious and who doesn't want to be pampered every once in a while.A few tips on this location though: - Especially on weekends, be prepared to wait for quite a while. When you arrive at the restaurant, they will probably give you a number. (Don't be surprised if they call a number that is greater than yours - they probably had not the right table-size ready yet.)- Don't order too much at once, but I suggest you order in small batches. That way, you can order according to your group's appetite and you also won't have all 12 dishes at once.- Make sure you order the Xiao Long Bao, as they do them really well here. (I suggest at least two orders ;-)As I mentioned in the beginning, this is the more luxurious dim-sum option, which also means that the price tag will be a little bit higher. So don't be surprised if you're losing a wad of cash...

BqAqF83Mpc9HDTHFlYU6rA.text: One of the better places for dim sum in town and right across from Yelp London HQ! Although can be confusing, there's two royal china's, except one is the royal china club and posher. But I don't do posh dim sum. (I've never been to alan yau's enterprises either...)What's more, I usually yum cha with a bunch of people and we order the whole menu. This time, only the two of us- which means this is a dim sum challenge. Hah! Not really, my friend and I decided to opt for 7 small dishes. So we got some classics- shanghai buns, bbq pork buns, siu mai and taro croquettes. Then some specials, crabmeat siu mai, pumpkin tofu and crispy sesame roll. Surprisingly, since they're only small dishes, it was the right amount of food and it's the first time I've walked away from dim sum quite comfortable! Although that might also be the oil, it was much less oily than other places I frequent! But it is slightly more expensive! and don't forget the 13% service charge too!Weird thing though, it's very much geared towards an english speaking clientele, I MISS MY BALLOT SHEET ORDERING. I do, it's more antisocial but seriously, dim sum is very much about catching up and chinese people don't stop to order. we pencil what we want on the ballot order and give it to the staff. done. way more efficient too!To end this review, and in the oh-so wise words of david and goliath. You dim sum, you win some. :)

5N4wxk327LduJaGWQ-PJNw.text: This was the worst service I ever received. Manager and deputy manager were both extremely rude and to be honest I've gotten better service from cheap five pound Chinese restaurants.....was very disappointed as I was a big fan but today the service proved that they have no class and no respect.Won't be coming back anytime soon

zuMcuFbknFlklgRbXbfoOA.text: Had dim sum while I was visiting London and I felt like I was back home in OC. My friends and I ordered all the classics and they were all delicious. We also ordered the crispy duck and it was so good with the scallions, cucumbers, and wrap.

mb45YIsqZ48LWjesgn-rUA.text: Came back and met a Bollywood celebrity (Arjun Rampal) who was also having lunch here. EPIC WIN.

XQ5Mp-HY3TQzyAxmoNLWeg.text: Went again on Saturday and it was extremely average. I was also very hungover and this tends to do weird things to my tastebuds. That being said, my friend who was in a very lucid state backed me up re the mediocrity. I guess the dim sum here can be inconsistent which is weird because I feel that insofar as a category of food goes, this is something they should be able to replicate without minimal difficulty. I suspect it has to do with the fact that last time I came the place was packed so everything had to be continually made fresh. Whereas when we went on Saturday while far from empty, it wasn't full at the time we got there, so perhaps the food we were served had been chilling in a basket but also outside of the steamer for a while. (But then again, it was still warm and I mean every dim sum place does this so I really have no clue...)

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

DUrNGmpxHfg_mvT-svSTeA.text: Wish I could put less then one star. Was the worst food I ever had. The noodles weren't cooked. The chicken was cold and when I asked for no mushrooms I was given extra. Also the waiters ignored us. And super over priced

W7Endpngetdpnxx9l4YnfQ.text: Portions small but very good However, service was rude and waiter over-charged for a beer we never ordered (had to argue to correct the charge).  Waiter asked if we wanted rice, we said yes, then when the bill came we discovered they charged almost 4 pounds per person for plain white rice.

UaqUrMFNht4wUrZsybNl1A.text: What better food to eat after a night of partying (well actually two nights connected by day partying) than some solid dim sum? The wait on a Sunday at 1pm was insane, but after what seemed like an eternity, our group of 6 were finally ushered to a table that could have seated 12. Generally a long wait makes me think the place was a good choice, and Royal China was no exception. Tea and waters were served promptly and we asked our server if they could rapidly bring us a large plate of fried noodles while we perused the dim sum menu as we were all on the brink of starvation (2 slices of pizza the day before apparently does not sustain me very well...). They followed through and within 5 minutes there were delicious green onion & garlic noodles for the table. Royal China does not do traditional dim sum cart service, so you get to peruse the menu and pick your favorites rather than selecting items off of a cart and having no idea what you're about to consume. I started with some shrimp and scallion dumplings, which were amazing. The dumpling skin was the perfect amount of gooey but not chewy and the shrimp were barely cooked through, rendering some amazing texture. I followed with a hot & sour soup, which was decent, but nothing special. It had lots of veggies, tofu, egg, and meat in it, but the soup could have been a lot spicier. Lastly I went with the roasted pork buns, which were absolutely foodgasmic! Plenty of filling on the inside and hot steamy bun on the outside, I devoured all three in record time. I also tried some of the Chinese broccoli and the sweet & sour prawns one of my friends ordered. For dessert we ordered custard buns for everyone, which had a really light but lovely sweetness to them and finished off the meal well. For the bowl of soup, dumplings (3), buns (3), and tea my total came to be 15 GBP (including a 13% enforced service charge), which I found very reasonable for the quality of food that Royal China delivered. Be careful not to confuse this place with the Royal China Club located one block down on the same street (I'm speaking from experience).

LnufVHihHwCp7IZitlnP2Q.text: What a superbly delightful place this is.Always packed at evenings so a tip is to call there for 6:30 for an almost guaranteed booking. The staff are respectful and humble as they are eager. If you had a game to see whether you could empty your teacup without someone filling it straight back up again... you would lose.Very reasonably priced for such high quality food. Soft shelled crab is a particular favourite of mine.They sort the food and environment, you have to the job of grabbing some good company. Enjoy!p.s - order a duck noodle soup to take away for the next day ;)

oFNztKc02N2-2OSKqWT-2g.text: We arrived a bit after 4 looking for Dim Sum.  Service was acceptable but could have been more friendly and helpful.  We were told that the Dim Sum service was about to end so that we needed to place our complete order immediately.  One of the soups we ordered turned out not to be available after the order was taken.  Dim Sum was good, won ton soup was OK.

xLznd-fVLwfIBO6aph9nug.text: Service with a scowl!Just not my kind of restaurant really. Overpriced and the decor kind of makes it feel like you're on a cruise ship. The service was unfriendly. I guess it's an okay choice for a special meal and the food was pretty good (the roast duck is worth at least 3 stars on it's own) but to be honest - some dim-sum, half a roast duck and a plate of fried seafood noodles for £96? Enough said.

UakOmbhmUlVnR0mbrLzLxw.text: Came for Sunday lunch. Took a number at 1pm and waited about 30mins. Good dim sum but the crispy aromatic duck was extremely dry. Service was chaotic to say the least. Our teapot needed refilling but we were ignored for easily an hour. When we eventually flagged someone down, they took the teapot and it never came back! Ordered dessert, waited another long while only to discover that our order was never put in. Sigh..

vnni-qYnuXTrG7P0fq3AEA.text: My title was a very suitable and honest description for this restaurant.  Our waiter gave you the attitude that he really did not want your business. We ordered our food in American English, Queen's English, four different Chinese dialects and also pointed the food items on the menu. He still had problems to understand the food items that we wanted to order. They gave you only one pot of tea for the entire table and they charged 2.20 Pound per person for tea. We paid 17.60 Pound just for one pot of tea !!They also automatically added service charge to your bill too.

jIn_E2dRuucL0bbbia4qSw.text: Only 3 stars for this restaurant as we visited for dinner and missed the lunch time dim sum menu (I'm sure I would have given it a higher rating otherwise!). A very nice looking venue, lovely decor and was quite busy on a Friday night so just as well we had booked in advance. We were shown to our table and looked through the medium sized menu.. I did struggle to find a main course that appealed and didn't pull at my purse strings at the same time. For starters, we ordered salt and pepper prawns which were not on the menu but we asked the waitress (who looked incredibly bored). They were lovely and the chili added a nice kick. Also ordered the pork dumplings which were delicious and were in a spicy sauce (yum). Both were decent sized portions. For mains, we ordered vegetable crispy noodles and duck and prawn rice wrapped in lotus leaf. The noodles came in a tasty sauce and the rice tasted good with the spicy sauce from the pork dumplings otherwise would have been a bit bland and dry. Pleased and full with the meal, we saw the bill came with a 13% recommended service charge. Unimpressed with the service and the lack of emotion from the staff, we told the waiter we did not want to pay it..upon which he practically forced us to despite us pointing out that it was only recommended. Not wanting to create a scene, we paid the full amount which came up to just over £22 each.Overall, it was a decent experience but I can't say I'll be visiting for dinner again but for lunch instead.

LXmKEBrXsu1ekjt96AG0ug.text: They have a sign that sticks out titled: Dim Sum. So, if you see that, you know you're close.I went to this place for dim sum with a cute girl. Because I was focused on her the whole time, I don't remember anything else about the restaurant, but it's probably great.

Z_HjCqGrNtmptKoWr59FEg.text: Great food. Just watch out when the bill arrives. Service is included but when they bring you machine (when paying by card) they take away the bill and they ask if you want to leave a tip.  Apart from this small point - I love this place.They do wonderful Dim Sum too- though there is usually a long wait during the weekend.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

u8dvpmobudiLx4ucEfQ_EA.text: Having lived in Asia, I usually avoid dim sum and chinese food when traveling in the West.  They usually disappoint... but I have to say, the quality of dim sum here in Royal China is comparable to dim sum restaurants in HK, Taiwan and Beijing.The dim sum skin is not thick nor gluey which is often the mistake.  We had the xiao long bao (the ones with the soup inside) which was almost at par with the xiao long bao of Din Tai Fung (Taiwan).  The hakao (prawn), siu mai (pork), and char siew bun (bbq pork) were great!  Then we had the crispy duck which they serve with sliced cucumber, spring onion, hoisin and wrapper.  A nice ending to the meal! We did not have space for dessert!The other good thing is the service staff spoke english! In HK and in Singapore, servers in good dim sum places only speak chinese!The only down side is they do not take reservations and we waited for a good 45mins.  So if I'm in London for only 5 days, will I come back?  Maybe not unless someone else waits in line while I shop in Selfridges.

gmANs7E07C1p2K3c-jgArg.text: Such Duck. It was absolutely delicious.  It's all I can really think about right now.

JMFv-yy57E1L_rcfGF1BSA.text: It's alright I suppose. Due to it's location it's full of rahs and Rupert's so not my cup of tea. However the food is good and apparently the Dim Sum is pretty authentic (not that I have a reference point.) I do like the tanks full of fish and lobsters that you pass on the way in, primarily because I can way at my aquatic friends and if the company gets boring I can always go over and talk to them.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

qIa8OvxtpHeFnjDLnFcCuQ.text: Fine dim sum is about observing the delicate preparation of bite-sized dumplings, the freshness and quality of the meat-mix, the moderate texture of the wraps and a very balanced taste due to the combination of meats. Garnishing like the lotus leaf and softness of the glutinous rice bring quality detailing that differentiates the a 4 and 5-Star. Complementing the dim sum menu is not something you leave to chance. It has to provide the assurance that the dim sum variety is respectable and the other dishes are simply "by-choice". That's because the art of dim sum eating is really about moderation to be enjoyed gracefully with friends and family. Therefore other dishes simply add only colour. The grilled duck and friend chicken is very lovely and worth every bite. You must complement the dish with their authentic dried chilli paste (deep red in colour). Royal China is a must stop if you want wonderful and comforting Chinese food. For us, it's most definitely one of the top 5 Chinese restaurants in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

-LmCuMJLas30J0UJTAfAEQ.text: Good upscale Chinese . We had the crispy duck with the pancakes it was good not great.. I would go again though it's convenient location .

jjHn5NHIgYxJGPXhOk8-mA.text: Nice food . Best dimsum in LondonMust try if you are dimsum lover . The location is accessible from many direction. Server are polite and price wise is reasonable.

wQA0pT-84LLHbn6F2hD4Zw.text: We've been going to Royal China for years, as their dim sum has been consistently good. There's usually a wait on the weekends, so that's always a good sign that this place is popular. During our most recent visit, we ordered all the usual dim sum fare which included our favorites; sticky rice in lotus leaf, shu mai, har gow, chicken feet, pork bao, etc. However, the reason why I took one star off is that a restaurant this size and this popular only has ONE high chair. Royal China is a family type restaurant as everything you eat is served family style. However, it's appalling that a restaurant like this only has a single high chair. Only until we were over halfway done, did the high chair become available and even though one of the workers was not happy that his colleague gave it to us. Please invest in more high chairs! Thanks.

BmSsZUf7XutMWEVZD7kgXw.text: Like the original on Queensway, this Royal China is one or two notches above all its competitors in SoHo (in terms of food, décor, and service); it's also more authentic than the Mich-* Chinese in London (like Hakkasan or Yauatcha). However, it is at least one notch below its branch in Singapore: the menu here is shorter, the dishes less refined, and there is much less innovation. Proof that standards for Chinese restaurants (Asian in general) are much higher in HK and Singapore than in London. Some classic dim sum dishes are surprisingly sub-par (eg. liao long bao, cheung fun); there is too much rice at the bottom of the FuKien fried rice below the thin layer of proteins and sauces; meatballs stuffed with crabmeat are excellent, though. Still, one of the better Chinese eateries in England.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

CRKf54GE0oR53-lE4BuPYw.text: Food:  We ordered the standard dim sum items - steam spare ribs, shrimp dumplings, steam chicken feet, crab soup dumplings, shu-maiFood rating:  3.5/5Service:  Standard for a Chinese restaurant, even for London.Service rating:  3.5/5Price:  Expect to pay about $5+ per item.Overall:  Authentic dim sum food in London and clean restaurant, but I am spoiled the fact that I live closer to better dim sum places.

133EVqIbdYTXrnqvQpajpw.text: I came here in March with Julia D and some of her friends to experience some London dim sum. We met up at 1:30 pm and the place was packed out with people hanging around by the door. If you put your name down a table will become available fairly soon (within 30 minutes) as the place is massive.We ordered an eclectic mix of food including steamed pork buns, fried dumplings, fried rice and won ton noodle soup. All of the food was delicious and cost less than £100 for four people. I've always struggled to find good Chinese food in London so I'm glad that I came to Royal China.

uwTnEFSFVlNpWZZZZ7FXfQ.text: Was a regular here for years but stopped coming here... had actually forgotten why so decided to visit for dinner...No complaints about the service but the food tasted bland.. simple dishes like schezuan prawns and egg fried rice just did not taste as good... i then remembered why i stopped coming here as it had lost its charm...Sad as started off really well here... perhaps like the other review said the royal china club is where the good food is now...

4tljPzNxkSMUhw7vE_52YQ.text: This place has no reason to have a 3.5 star rating.  Service was terrible, to say the least, the food was ok.  One of our dishes didn't arrive until 20 minutes after all of the other orders had arrived.  They kept checking in at our ticket, but that did nothing as the problem was not corrected and they had to be asked several times to bring the dish  I would not waste my time patronizing this establishment.  They seem to have a large fan base but no diners seemed particularly happy or overjoyed with their food!

gLyD7KywmOYj16kPWPaZBQ.text: Authentic Cantonese restaurant and really good taste! A little expensive but it's worth to give a shot

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

amBaRNUYOXogJaRoq_qh6Q.text: It's basically the FAKE version of "the royal china club", thats why the food quality and the presentation is absolutely terrible.Literally imagine below average messy chinese food coming from a fancy pricy menu on the table. We ordered the roast duck which was over cooked Lemon chicken which was very dry and beyond sweet. Beef and ginger which was very smelly and chewy.And the starter which was fried squid was cold and again not fresh, we paid 150£ which was absolute waste of money and literally left the food on the table and will never come back or recommend that place.

wuLBoBzIHLso_vp6Klw_1w.text: Very nice upscale Cantonese restaurant with delicious food and awesome service, something can't be found in even New York

GEZnqM161LxFU1-FomJtJg.text: I'm not sure why other people are hating on this place. I come here every time I'm in London. The dim sum is wonderful, the egg tarts are amazing! Food is authentic and well made. Definitely give this place a try if you're craving good Cantonese style Chinese food

UWHt_5e5prP20jF0GFUuXg.text: Really poor customer service - will never be back. Served us raw Siu Mai dim sum which our toddler ate some of before we realised. Manager laughed and didn't seem apologetic and didn't even bother to take it off the bill for us.  Our son wandered off for a second while we were attending to our infant and we were so worried I asked in English if they could make an announcement the waitress seemed annoyed and said "I don't understand Chinese" (what the heck!?). Luckily our son returned (albeit in tears). There are much better dim sum places out there.

LW1VmKxcnKipGtbtPg7CNw.text: My friend Vina and her husband invited me and Matt B to meet them here. I've had a lot of dim sum in San Francisco but this was my first London experience. We ordered har gao, shrimp and chive dumplings, steamed pork buns, won ton noodle soup, shrimp fried rice, noodles with shrimp inside, fried dumplings, custard tarts, and lotus buns. Everything was delicious. Four adults and a two year old: the total was 95 pounds. Not horrible for a perfectly prepared meal and two hours of endless tea. Service was prompt. We waited 30 minutes for a table at 1:30pm on a Sunday. It seemed to get less crowded around 3. People who like good Chinese food need to come here asap.

VyTM3ktxcpCyGCi1UoZo6w.text: This place has tasty dim sum and is my to go to place whenever I'm in London - I'm of Asian decent and also had dim sum all of my life from various restaurants from Asia to the US...The ambiance is good, it's not rough Chinatown environment but more of a classier calmer establishment with mixed crowds (many people were not Asian when I go).I am especially a fan of their chicken feet (in brown sauce) and their steam roast pork buns. They were able to get the buns perfectly steamed, with the fillings perfectly stuffed and taste. I also had other dishes which were good including the Singapore Curry Noodles.The service was good and they were very prompt in serving me my dishes, giving me more tea and setting the bill when I was ready. They even gave me a lovely container to pack some of the takeaway steam roast pork burns because they were so good, i wanted to take some more with me for my flight home!

cSyUNCxKdDjxgzKMOcjl7Q.text: This place must make an absolute mint!! A constant stream of people make it almost certain you will have to Que on the weekends but weekdays are usually quieter. The food is very good and having been forced to try other dim sum / yum cha options this is the only place that we always return to. The service is typical Chinese restaurant style.. seat, eat, get out with minimum fuss. They will only seat you when the whole group is here... Don't even bother to argue or negotiate with them as it will fall on deaf ears and they won't care if you take your business else where, it's not goin to effect them. The food is usually delivered within minutes of ordering and I've never had bad food here. The seating is functional and they can cater for couples or large groups. Price is very reasonable in comparison to other places similar but for a much higher standard of food.

pcmHguiGY_-XkXdkntkyPg.text: So this is the first place we tried near our new flat when we moved in. The sea spice aubergine is the best i've had in London, which is saying A LOT. Chinese food here is quite mediocre for the most part. We had another dish that was like kungpao chicken or something and it didn't have enough veggies. For some bizarre reason restaurants here always give you a ton of meat with no veggies and too much salt. We had eggrolls for starters which were also pretty good.Unfortunately, it is on the pricey side for chinese food - 50GBP for 2 ppl but it is the price you pay in London. The service was fantastic, however. We actually did not have to ask our waiter to refill our water, which is a feat in itself.

flBu3vJb9ErS9JBcRV19Fw.text: What is it with Baker Street? It's either a chain or ridiculously overpriced - either way the quality of food is pretty sub-standard.Popped in for a lunch meeting and had a variety of dim sum. It was ok - it was no Drunken Monkey. It seemed very popular for work lunches and a couple of large groups came in on an office lunchtime jolly.The service wasn't particularly friendly... in fact it was downright frosty. Brrr!I'm no vegetarian but I felt sorry for the fish and lobsters in the tank on the way in. They looked sad.I won't be hurrying back.I disagree with previous reviews, you CAN get fantastic Chinese cuisine in London. In fact you can get fantastic cuisine of any kind in London - it's a culinary capital - however, Royal China is not the place to find it.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Dim Sum selection

JF1wdpDe22jZWPSrwvZKsw.text: Food is good but a bit overpriced. Sadly staff is not attentive at all. It all takes too long. Maybe you need to be in big group to 'gain' attention.  ;-)
